Both professionals, *linguists/language people/translators/engineers/developpers* and *linguists/language people/translators/engineers/developpers* should be behind the customisation of NMT. 

Custom NMT is not an *isolated/let-alone* process in the translation process, it is just another piece of the full workflow.

A good strategy for training custom NMT should take into account the language pair and the final *purpose/goal/usage/end* of the system, among other things.

Custom NMT usually works better if some *in-domain/domain-related/domain-specific/specific/domain* data, and not only generic, is available.

Not only corpora play a role in customisation: also *techniques* may be explored to get the best of both data and technology advances. 

Some preprocessing steps like identifying units in texts, that is *tokenization/tokenisation*, or splitting words in smaller parts called *subwords/sub-words*  are needed in order to train NMT systems.
